an8.36:0.4: “Mendicants, there are these three grounds for making merit.
an8.36:0.6: Giving, ethical conduct, and meditation are all grounds for making merit.
an8.36:2.1: First, someone has practiced a little giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:2.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn among disadvantaged humans.
an8.36:3.1: Next, someone has practiced a moderate amount of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:3.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn among well-off humans.
an8.36:4.1: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:4.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods of the Four Great Kings.
an8.36:4.3: There, the Four Great Kings themselves have practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So they surpass them in ten respects:
an8.36:4.4: divine life span, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
an8.36:5.1: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:5.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods of the Thirty Three.
an8.36:5.3: There, Sakka, lord of gods, has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …
an8.36:6.1: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:6.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods of Yama.
an8.36:6.3: There, the god Suyāma has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …
an8.36:7.1: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:7.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Joyful Gods.
an8.36:7.3: There, the god Santusita has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …
an8.36:8.1: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:8.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods Who Love to Create.
an8.36:8.3: There, the god Sunimmita has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …
an8.36:9.1: Next, someone has practiced a lot of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.
an8.36:9.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others.
an8.36:9.3: There, the god Vasavattī has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects:
an8.36:9.4: divine life span, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.
an8.36:9.5: These are the three grounds for making merit.”
